newsitem.title: USA: US budget gives $24 bln for kids health--Domenici.
newsitem.headline: US budget gives $24 bln for kids health--Domenici.

text.p: Senate Budget Committee Chairman Pete Domenici said, just hours before details of a U.S. budget deal were expected to be announceed, that the pact would include $24 billion for childrens' healthcare and most likely a 15-cent per-pack cigarette tax.

"We had to agree to the $24 billion in child heathcare but the Senate had already agreed to that and I think that is a good cause as long as the money is spent right," he said in an interview on Cable News Network "Moneyline" television program.

When asked if the U.S. cigarette tax would increase by 20 cents a pack, Domenici said: "It's not going to be that high...I think the number that is out is 15 (cents) and we don't start it for a year or two."

A Republican source told Reuters that the cigarette tax will rise by up to 15 cents a pack over the next five years under the new budget agreement that Congress and the Clinton administration hope to reach Monday night.

Domenici also said a capital gains tax cut has been worked out and "will be a little bit better than everyone is reporting." An immediate capital gains tax cut to 20 percent from 28 percent is expected, with a drop to 18 percent in 2001 for investments held more than five years.
